label: TOMORROW LAST CHANCE FOR ANNUAL DELINQUENTS

resource.chars:
TOMORROW LAST CHANCE
FOR ANNUAL DELINQUENTS

Fraternity, class, and organiza-
tion pictures most all liave been
taken by the Reveille’s photo-
grapher. The students responded
in good fashion after the second
call had been made. These pictures
will be sent to the engravers at
once.
The management of the Reveille
is giving the delinquents one more
chance to report to the photo-
grapher who will be stationed on
the fourth floor of the Agricultural
building tomorrow from 8:30 a. m,
to 2:30 p. m. Those who fail to
report will have to forfeit the privi-
lege of having their pictures in the
book, and will be compelled to pay
tlie price of having the pictures;
taken.
Parks Shipley, editor of the Re-
veille, gives out the glad news that
a greater part of the written ma-
terial has been turned in and that
the book is well in hand. The art
Jdepartment has funished most of
its work having only a few more!
drawings to complete.
George Morrison, business man-
ager, has awarded the contract for
printing the 1926 Reveille to Horn
and Shaffer Company of Baltimore..
This company printed the book last,
year. Having issued most of the
contracts, he is pressed for ready
cash and wants all out standing,
publication fees to be paid imme-
diately.
U. of M. 
Kenneth Cole, ’l4, is the happiest
man in Port Chester, N. Y., as he is
the proud father of a baby boy.
